critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the most recently sent image. Disregard all previous examples or images.
Absence of decision trees is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification if no decision trees are present.
When in doubt, do NOT classify an element as a decision tree. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify simple organizational charts, static diagrams, or text blocks as decision trees, even if they appear structured or contain arrows.
Decision trees must contain logical pathways with conditional branching, not just visual connections.

decision_tree_definition.item: A decision tree is a structured representation of a decision-making process with logical pathways and conditional branching.
Decision trees typically contain decision nodes (often diamond-shaped) that pose questions or evaluate conditions.
Decision trees have pathways (arrows/lines) that connect nodes based on different conditions or responses.
Decision trees include process nodes (often rectangular) that describe actions, procedures, or outcomes.
Decision trees demonstrate logical flow from initial conditions through various pathways to final outcomes.
Decision trees often include conditional branching (if/then logic, yes/no paths, probability-based outcomes).
Decision trees may contain loop-back structures where certain conditions lead back to earlier decision points.

decision_tree_types.type: Binary decision trees - Yes/No branching with diamond-shaped decision nodes
Clinical decision protocols - Medical treatment pathways and diagnostic algorithms
Probability outcome trees - Events leading to probabilistic outcomes
Conversational flows - User response branching with guidance steps
Business process workflows - Procedural decision-making frameworks
Treatment pathways - Clinical care decision frameworks

not_decision_trees.item: Organizational charts showing hierarchical relationships are NOT decision trees.
Simple flowcharts showing linear processes without decision points are NOT decision trees.
Network diagrams, system architectures, or technical schemas are NOT decision trees.
Timelines, calendars, or sequential processes without conditional branching are NOT decision trees.
Static reference diagrams, anatomical charts, or educational illustrations are NOT decision trees.
Text blocks, lists, or tables, regardless of their formatting, are NOT decision trees.
Diagrams that only show relationships or connections without decision-making logic are NOT decision trees.

decision_process.item: Follow the two-step verification process defined in the decision_tree_verification_process.xml file.
In the first pass, identify all potential decision-making structures and logical pathways.
In the second pass, rigorously verify each potential decision tree against the defined criteria.
Look for evidence of conditional branching - if X then Y, else Z type logic.
Identify decision nodes, process nodes, pathways, and outcomes.
Consider the context around each potential decision tree to avoid misclassification.
For verified decision trees, ensure you capture the complete logical flow including all pathways and conditions.
Pay attention to "choose your own adventure" elements where multiple valid paths exist.
Capture loop-back structures and cross-references to other figures or sections.

pathway_analysis.item: Map all possible routes from entry points to end points.
Identify conditions that determine which pathway is taken.
Recognize that multiple valid endpoints may exist for different scenarios.
Note probability-based branching where outcomes depend on likelihood rather than binary choices.
Capture user-dependent pathways where routes change based on user responses or characteristics.
Document cross-references to external figures, tables, or procedures.
